title: Joel Bitonio
text:
Joel Michael Bitonio (born October 11, 1991) is an <a href="American%20football">American football</a> <a href="Guard%20%28gridiron%20football%29">guard</a> for the <a href="Cleveland%20Browns">Cleveland Browns</a> of the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> (NFL). He was drafted by the Browns in the second round of the <a href="2014%20NFL%20Draft">2014 NFL Draft</a>. He played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> at <a href="Nevada%20Wolf%20Pack%20football">Nevada</a>.
Early years.
Bitonio attended <a href="Woodrow%20Wilson%20Classical%20High%20School">Long Beach Wilson High School</a> in <a href="Long%20Beach%2C%20California">Long Beach, California</a>, where he was a three-sport star. He was named to the Long Beach Press Telegram's Dream Team for football and basketball as a senior. In <a href="high%20school%20football">football</a>, he was a two-time All-league selection and was the Moore League Lineman of the Year. He was a first-team All-conference selection and was named second-team All-state by "<a href="CBS%20Interactive">MaxPreps.com</a>". Bitonio also lettered in <a href="track%20%26amp%3B%20field">track & field</a> as a senior. He led the league in the shot put, recording a top-throw of 15.39 meters at the 2009 CIF Southern Section Division 1 Prelims.
College career.
Bitonio attended the <a href="University%20of%20Nevada%2C%20Reno">University of Nevada</a> from 2009 to 2013. He started 39 consecutive games from his <a href="redshirt%20%28college%20sports%29">redshirt</a> sophomore to senior seasons. As a senior, he was an All-<a href="Mountain%20West%20Conference">Mountain West Conference</a> selection.
Professional career.
2014 season.
Bitonio was considered one of the top offensive tackle prospects for the <a href="2014%20NFL%20Draft">2014 NFL Draft</a>. He was drafted by the <a href="Cleveland%20Browns">Cleveland Browns</a> in the second round (35th overall) of the <a href="2014%20NFL%20Draft">2014 NFL Draft</a>.
2015 season.
On December 7, 2015, Bitonio was placed on injured reserve.
2016 season.
On October 14, 2016, Bitonio was again placed on injured reserve after sustaining a foot injury in Week 5.
2017 season.
On March 9, 2017, Bitonio signed a five-year contract extension with the Browns through the 2022 season. He was named to his first Pro Bowl and was named second-team All-Pro after starting all 16 games at left guard.
2020 season.
Bitonio was named to the <a href="2020%20All-Pro%20Team">2020 NFL All-Pro Team</a>, along with three of his teammates: defensive end <a href="Myles%20Garrett">Myles Garrett</a>, tackle <a href="Jack%20Conklin">Jack Conklin</a>, and fellow guard <a href="Wyatt%20Teller">Wyatt Teller</a>. Bitonio was placed on the reserve/<a href="COVID-19">COVID-19</a> list by the team on January 5, 2021, and activated on January 15.
2021 season.
On November 10, 2021, Bitonio signed a three-year, $48 million contract extension through the 2025 season.
Personal life.
His father, Mike Bitonio, was a <a href="mixed%20martial%20arts">mixed martial arts</a> fighter. He died at the age of 45 in 2010.
